trial_identification.studytitle: The Effects of Balance Exercises on Postural Control and Gait in Older Women with risk of Falls
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Effects of Balance Exercises On Postural Sway And Gait In Pre Frail Older Women at Risk of Falls

interventions.interventions: Exercise Group trained classes with static and dynamic balance exercises. Balance disks and tables, foams and balls were used for the exercises. The program was composed by exercises that trained postural control during bipodal and unipodal stance, altering surfaces and visual information, avoid obstacles and ankle and hip strategy. Exercises were performed in groups with a physiotherapist, 1 hour twice a week for 12 week.
interventions.comparator: Control group trained classes with stretching and active range of motion exercises for upper limbs. Subjects performed active exercises like shoulder flexion, abduction and rotation (without resistance), scapular adduction (with theraband) and elbow flexion and extension (without resistance). Subjects also underwent stretching of cervical and lumbar muscles (seating position). Exercises were performed in groups with a physiotherapist, 1 hour once a week for 12 week.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Linear and nonlinear measures of postural fluctuations assessed during a quiet upright standing on a force plate
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 12 week after intervention commencement

primaryOutcome.outcome: Temporal and spatial parameters of gait, assessed by GAITRite System
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 12 week after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Falls ocurrence. Subjects were asked weekly about the ocurrence of falls. Falls were recorded in weekly interviews.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, and at 3, 6, 9 and 12 month after intervention commencement
Baseline and 12 week after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time of Sit to Stand test (5 repetitions)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 12 week after intervention commencement
Baseline and 12 week after intervention commencement

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time of Alternate Step Test (8 repetitions)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 12 week after intervention commencement

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Community-dwelling older adults; age 65 yeras or over; history of at least one fall 12 months prior to data collection; pre-frail according Phenotype of Frailty; ability to walk 6 meters without human assistance.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Cognitive impairment; neurologic conditions like Parkinson and stroke; initiate any intervention after randomization.

trial_design.concealment: the person who determined if a subject was eligible for inclusion in the trial was unaware, when this decision was made, to which group the subject would be allocated, because allocation was done by another investigator, after the subject was included in the trial.
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a randomisation table created by computer software (i.e. computerised sequence generation)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of the study was to evaluate the effects of a program with balance exercises on postural control, gait, falls and fear of falling of older women with history of falls. Exercises trained center of gravity control during challenge situations
